statements.name: PROC TABULATE
statements.description: Displays descriptive statistics in tabular format.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: specifies the confidence level for the confidence limits.

arguments.name: CLASSDATA=
arguments.description: specifies a secondary data set that contains the combinations of values of class variables to include in tables and output data sets.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: specifies the text for the entries in the table of contents.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY-variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: EXCLNPWGT
arguments.description: excludes observations with nonpositive weights.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: excludes from tables and output data sets all combinations of class variable values that are not in the CLASSDATA= data set.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies a default format for each cell in the table.

arguments.name: FORMCHAR=
arguments.description: defines the characters to use to construct the table outlines and dividers.

arguments.name: position
arguments.description: identifies the position of one or more characters in the SAS formatting-character string. A space or a comma separates the positions.

arguments.name: formatting-character
arguments.description: lists the characters to use for the specified positions.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: considers missing values as valid values for class variables.

arguments.name: NOSEPS
arguments.description: eliminates horizontal separator lines from the row titles and the body of the table.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: disables parallel processing of the input data set.This option overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS unless the system option is restricted.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: orders the values of a class variable according to the specified order.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their ascending formatted values. If no format has been assigned to a numeric class variable, then the default format, BEST12., is used. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: orders values by descending frequency count.

arguments.name: UNFORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment. This sort sequence is particularly useful for displaying dates chronologically.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set.

arguments.name: QMARKERS=
arguments.description: specifies the sample size to use for the P2 quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: QMETHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: OS
arguments.description: uses order statistics. PROC UNIVARIATE uses this technique.

arguments.name: P2
arguments.description: uses the P2 method to approximate the quantile.

arguments.name: QNTLDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the mathematical definition to calculate quantiles.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for specific areas of the table.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: enables parallel processing of the input data set. This option overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS unless the system option is restricted.

arguments.name: TRAP
arguments.description: enables floating point exception recovery during data processing beyond the recovery that is provided by normal SAS FPE handling.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the variance divisor to use in the calculation of the variance and standard deviation.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus one

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: Identifies class variables for the table. Class variables determine the categories that PROC TABULATE uses to calculate statistics.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables that the procedure uses to group the data. Variables in a CLASS statement are referred to as class variables.

arguments.name: ASCENDING
arguments.description: specifies to sort the class variable values in ascending order.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies to sort the class variable values in descending order.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: excludes from tables and output data sets all combinations of class variables that are not found in the preloaded range of user-defined formats.

arguments.name: GROUPINTERNAL
arguments.description: specifies not to apply formats to the class variables when PROC TABULATE groups the values to create combinations of class variables.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: considers missing values as valid class variable levels. Special missing values that represent numeric values (the letters A through Z and the underscore (_) character) are each considered as a separate value.

arguments.name: MLF
arguments.description: enables PROC TABULATE to use the format label or labels for a given range or overlapping ranges to create subgroup combinations when a multilabel format is assigned to a class variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: specifies the order to group the levels of the class variables in the output.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: orders values by descending frequency count.

arguments.name: UNFORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment. This sort sequence is particularly useful for displaying dates chronologically.

arguments.name: PRELOADFMT
arguments.description: specifies that all formats are preloaded for the class variables.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for page dimension text and class variable name headings.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

statements.name: CLASSLEV
statements.description: Specifies a style element for class variable level value headings.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more class variables from the CLASS statement for which you want to specify a style element.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides for class variable level value headings.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: Specifies a numeric variable that contains the frequency of each observation.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. If you use the FREQ statement, then the procedure assumes that each observation represents

statements.name: KEYLABEL
statements.description: Labels a keyword for the duration of the PROC TABULATE step. PROC TABULATE uses the label anywhere that the specified keyword would otherwise appear.

arguments.name: keyword
arguments.description: specifies a statistic keyword.

arguments.name: description
arguments.description: specifies the keyword label.

statements.name: KEYWORD
statements.description: Specifies a style element for keyword headings.

arguments.name: keyword
arguments.description: specifies the keyword statistic.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides for the keyword headings.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: TABLE
statements.description: Describes a table to be printed.

arguments.name: column-expression
arguments.description: defines the columns in the table.

arguments.name: page-expression
arguments.description: defines the pages in a table.

arguments.name: row-expression
arguments.description: defines the rows in the table.

arguments.name: BOX=
arguments.description: specifies text for the empty box above the row titles.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: writes the page-dimension text in the box. If the page-dimension text does not fit, then it is placed in its default position above the box, and the box remains empty.

arguments.name: BOX=
arguments.description: specifies text and a style override for the empty box above the row titles.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: writes the page-dimension text in the box. If the page-dimension text does not fit, then it is placed in its default position above the box, and the box remains empty.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: writes the quoted string in the box. Any string that does not fit in the box is truncated.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: writes the name (or label, if the variable has one) of a variable in the box. Any name or label that does not fit in the box is truncated.

arguments.name: CAPTION=
arguments.description: specifies a caption text string to add before each table.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY-variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: CONDENSE
arguments.description: prints as many complete logical pages as possible on a single printed page or, if possible, prints multiple pages of tables that are too wide to fit on a page one below the other on a single page, instead of on separate pages.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: enables you to name the link in the HTML table of contents that points to the ODS output of the table that is produced by using the TABLE statement.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY-variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: FORMAT_PRECEDENCE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the format that is specified for the page dimension (PAGE), row dimension (ROW), or column dimension (COLUMN) is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: specifies that the format that is specified for the page dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: specifies that the format that is specified for the row dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: COLUMN
arguments.description: specifies that the format that is specified for the column dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: FUZZ=
arguments.description: supplies a numeric value against which analysis variable values and table cell values other than frequency counts are compared to eliminate trivial values (absolute values less than the FUZZ= value) from computation and printing.

arguments.name: INDENT=
arguments.description: specifies the number of spaces to indent nested row headings, and suppresses the row headings for class variables.

arguments.name: MISSTEXT=
arguments.description: supplies up to 256 characters of text to be printed for table cells that contain missing values.

arguments.name: MISSTEXT=
arguments.description: supplies up to 256 characters of text to be printed and specifies a style override for table cells that contain missing values.

arguments.name: NOCELLMERGE
arguments.description: specifies that data cells are not merged with other data cells in the table.

arguments.name: NOCONTINUED
arguments.description: suppresses the continuation message, continued, that is displayed at the bottom of tables that span multiple pages.

arguments.name: PRINTMISS
arguments.description: prints all values that occur for a class variable each time headings for that variable are printed, even if there are no data for some of the cells that these headings create.

arguments.name: ROW=
arguments.description: specifies whether all title elements in a row crossing are allotted space even when they are blank.

arguments.name: CONSTANT
arguments.description: allots space to all row titles even if the title has been blanked out. (For example, N=' '.)

arguments.name: FLOAT
arguments.description: divides the row title space equally among the nonblank row titles in the crossing.

arguments.name: RTSPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the number of print positions to allot to all of the headings in the row dimension, including spaces that are used to print outlining characters for the row headings.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for parts of the table other than table cells.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

arguments.name: STYLE_PRECEDENCE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the style that is specified for the page dimension (PAGE), row dimension (ROW), or column dimension (COLUMN or COL) is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: specifies that the style that is specified for the page dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: specifies that the style that is specified for the row dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

arguments.name: COLUMN
arguments.description: specifies that the style that is specified for the column dimension is applied to the contents of the table cells.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: Identifies numeric variables to use as analysis variables.

arguments.name: analysis-variable
arguments.description: identifies the analysis variables in the table. Analysis variables are numeric variables for which PROC TABULATE calculates statistics. The values of an analysis variable can be continuous or discrete.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides for analysis variable name headings.

arguments.name: <PARENT>
arguments.description: specifies that the data cell use the style element of its parent heading.

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change.

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the variables that are specified in the VAR statement. The variable does not have to be an integer.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: Specifies weights for analysis variables in the statistical calculations.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the analysis variables. The values of the variable do not have to be integers.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
